issues.description: The problem statement (UML and attribute list) specifies numberOfTutors as an int, but the solution implementation declares the field as a short. This is a type mismatch for a core attribute: students reading the UML will expect an int field and will likely implement constructor/setter/getter signatures using int. The solution's use of short deviates from the specification and can confuse students when they compare their work to the reference (or when tests expect int-based signatures).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute type consistent across artifacts. Prefer changing the solution field to int so it matches the UML and problem statement: replace 'private short numberOfTutors;' with 'private int numberOfTutors;'. Alternatively, if short is intentional, update the problem statement/UML to indicate 'short' for numberOfTutors — but keeping int is clearer and consistent with the rest of the integer attributes.

issues.description: The constructor in the solution takes a short parameter for numberOfTutors, whereas the problem statement (UML and attribute list) expects numberOfTutors to be an int. This constructor parameter type mismatch can mislead students about the expected signature and the order/types of constructor parameters they should implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Adjust the solution constructor to use int for the numberOfTutors parameter to match the UML and problem description: change the constructor signature to 'public Lecture(String lectureName, int numberOfInscribedStudents, int numberOfGuestStudents, int numberOfLecturers, int numberOfTutors) { ... }'. If short was intentional, update the problem statement to document the short type (less recommended).

issues.description: The setter for numberOfTutors in the solution accepts a short parameter (setNumberOfTutors(short)), while the problem statement and UML imply numberOfTutors is an int (so the setter would be expected to accept an int). This method parameter mismatch between the reference solution and the specification can confuse students about the correct setter signature to implement and about types they should use elsewhere.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the setter parameter type consistent with the UML/specification. Change the solution method signature to 'public void setNumberOfTutors(int numberOfTutors)' and update the field type to int as suggested above. If short is required for some special reason, document this choice in the problem statement and adjust the UML accordingly.
